### Input:

- Empty image dimensions

# Image Flipping in Computer Vision

Image flipping is one of the most fundamental geometric transformations in image processing and computer vision. It is widely used for data augmentation in deep learning to increase dataset diversity and improve model generalization.

## Types of Image Flipping

### Horizontal Flip (Left-Right Mirror)
A horizontal flip creates a mirror image along the vertical axis (y-axis). For a pixel at position $(x, y)$ in an image of width $W$:

$$x_{new} = W - 1 - x$$
$$y_{new} = y$$

This transformation can be represented as a matrix operation:

$$\begin{bmatrix} x_{new} \\ y_{new} \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} -1 & 0 & W-1 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}$$

### Vertical Flip (Top-Bottom Mirror)
A vertical flip creates a mirror image along the horizontal axis (x-axis). For a pixel at position $(x, y)$ in an image of height $H$:

$$x_{new} = x$$
$$y_{new} = H - 1 - y$$

The transformation matrix is:

$$\begin{bmatrix} x_{new} \\ y_{new} \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -1 & H-1 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}$$

## Implementation with NumPy

In NumPy, flipping can be efficiently done using array slicing with step -1:

- **Horizontal flip**: `image[:, ::-1]` reverses the order of columns
- **Vertical flip**: `image[::-1, :]` reverses the order of rows

## Applications in Deep Learning

1. **Data Augmentation**: Flipping images during training helps models become invariant to left-right or top-bottom orientations.

2. **Test-Time Augmentation (TTA)**: Predictions on flipped versions of test images can be averaged for more robust results.

3. **Symmetric Object Detection**: For symmetric objects, horizontal flipping doubles the effective training data.

## Example

Consider a $2 \times 3$ grayscale image:

$$\text{Original} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 4 & 5 & 6 \end{bmatrix}$$

After horizontal flip:
$$\text{Flipped}_H = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 2 & 1 \\ 6 & 5 & 4 \end{bmatrix}$$

After vertical flip:
$$\text{Flipped}_V = \begin{bmatrix} 4 & 5 & 6 \\ 1 & 2 & 3 \end{bmatrix}$$
